tool.name: evalExtremes

param.name: inputLayer
param.datatype: Feature Class or Feature Layer or Table or dBASE Table or Table View or Text File
param.dialogReference: The input layer or table containing the values to be evaluated. Feature Classes, Geodatabase Tables, and CSV files are supported as input. Note that when using a CSV file, you must write the results to a new file. You will not have the option of writing the output values directly to the input table.

param.name: fields
param.dialogReference: The fields in the input dataset to evaluate. The fields must be numeric (Short, Long, Float, and Double), but don't all have to be of the same format. When using a mix of formats in the input, the output value field will use the most complex field type represented in the data. Short < Long < Float < Double

param.name: evalType
param.dialogReference:
The evaluation type that will be used to define the winning field and value.

  • Highest Value - returns the highest discovered value and respective field name per row

  • Lowest Value - returns the lowest discovered value and respective field name per row

param.name: tieBreakerHandling
param.dialogReference:
Determines how the tool handles situations in which multiple columns have the discovered Highest/Lowest value.

  • First - returns the first column with the discovered Highest/Lowest value

  • Last - returns the last column with the discovered Highest/Lowest value

param.name: winningFieldName
param.dialogReference: The tool creates a new field who's value will be the name of the field that has the winning value. This will be the name of that new field.

param.name: winningFieldAlias
param.dialogReference: The tool creates a new field who's value will be the name of the field that contained the winning value. This will be the alias of that new field.

param.name: winningFieldValue
param.expression: Use Winning Field's Name | Use Winning Field's Alias
param.dialogReference:
The newly created Winning Field will contain the name of the field that originally contained the winning values. There are two options for how this value is populated.

  • Use Winning Field's Alias - The winning field's alias (instead of name) will be used as the value.

  • Use Winning Field's Name - The winning field's name (instead of alias) will be used as the value.

param.name: winningValueName
param.dialogReference: The tool creates a new field that contains the winning value. This will be the name of that new field.

param.name: winningValueAlias
param.dialogReference: The tool creates a new field that contains the winning value. This will be the alias of that new field.

param.name: tieDetectionName
param.dialogReference: A field is created to document the detection of a tie for the Highest/Lowest values. This is the name of that output field.

param.name: tieDetectionAlias
param.dialogReference: A field is created to document the detection of a tie for the Highest/Lowest values. This is the alias of that output field.

param.name: outputType
param.dialogReference:
Describes where the output will be created. This parameter will be disabled and default to "Create Copy" if the input is not a geodatabase item.

  • Modify Input - New fields and results will be written directly to the input layer.

  • Create Copy - Input will be copied and new fields and results will be written to the copy.

param.name: outputFile
param.dialogReference: If Output Type is set to Create Copy, the output will be written to the specified location.

tool.summary: Evaluates each record in a table across a defined set of columns to find the highest or lowest values. These results are written to three new fields in either the input dataset or a new output file. The three new fields describe, for each row, the highest or lowest value in the evaluation, the name of the field that contained that value, and whether there was a tie between the winning field and another field.
tool.usage: Use this tool to find the highest or lowest value across a series for each record. For example, if annual rainfall for an area is listed as fields (e.g. rain2010, rain2011, rain2012 etc) in a dataset, identify which year had the highest rainfall for each record.
